I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  On 4 April 2005, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the Nam Theun 2 
Hydroelectric Project1 (the Project). The Project is to help the Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
(Lao PDR) generate sustainable electricity from a renewable hydropower resource for use 
domestically and for export to Thailand, earning much-needed revenue in hard currency for 
poverty reduction and environmental protection programs. 
 
2.  ADB assistance for the Project consists of a $20 million ordinary capital resources loan 
to the Government of the Lao PDR for (i) its equity investment into the Nam Theun 2 Power 
Company  (NTPC)  through  Lao  Holding  State  Enterprises,  (ii)  a  $50  million  political  risk 
guarantee, and (iii) a $50 million direct loan2 to NTPC. Other project financiers include the World 
Bank,  European  Investment  Bank,  Nordic  Investment  Bank,  Agence  Française  de 
Développement, and private commercial banks. The total project cost is estimated to be $1,250 
million.  
 
3.  The Project will construct a transbasin hydropower station with a capacity of 1,070 
megawatts. A 39-meter-high dam is being built on the Nam Theun River, creating a reservoir of 
450 square kilometers (km). Water released from the power station will be discharged through a 
27-km channel before being discharged into the Xe Bang Fai River. 
 
4.  The Project will have a variety of negative impacts on the environment and also social 
impacts on the people who live in the reservoir area, upstream and downstream areas, and in 
the watershed of the Nakai-Nam Theun National Protected Area. Social impacts of the Project 
include (i) resettlement of 1,200 households living on the Nakai plateau in the reservoir area; (ii) 
acquisition of land for construction of the project facilities, particularly the land for construction of 
the downstream channel; and (iii) associated impacts on the 37 villages along the Nam Theun 
River downstream of the dam, on the 31 villages in the watershed upstream of the reservoir, 
and on about 200 villages along the Xe Bang Fai River downstream of the power station. 
 
5.  The Government has requested assistance from ADB to ensure that these negative 
impacts are appropriately mitigated. The proposed technical assistance (TA)3 will provide this 
support. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
6.  The  Project  has  been  designed  to  be  a  model  for  large  hydropower  projects.  Its 
development and implementation have involved (i) extensive consultations with project-affected 
people and other stakeholders; (ii) an environmental management program aimed at mitigating 
environmental impacts and biodiversity conservation; (iii) a comprehensive social development 
program aimed at restoring and improving the livelihoods of the reservoir resettlers and of 
upstream  and  downstream  villages;  and  (iv)  a  multi-level  monitoring  scheme  involving  an 
independent  panel  of  social  and  environmental  experts,  the  lenders’  technical  advisor,  an 
independent  monitoring  agency,  and  the  international  financial  institutions  (IFI).  ADB 
participates in the IFI monitoring activities to ensure that the Project is being implemented in

accordance  with  the  Project’s  legal  documents  and  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  social  and

7.  After 2.5 years of construction, the Project has reached a critical milestone—closure of 
the Nakai dam diversion tunnel, which commences the reservoir filling. In 2009, NTPC will start 
testing the water release to the Nam Theun River and will also gradually release water to the Xe 
Bang Fai River. With closing of the diversion tunnel and filling of the reservoir, impacts will occur 
to affected persons on the Nakai plateau, and in the upstream and downstream areas. 
 
8.  It is therefore very important for the Government, ADB, and other IFIs to closely monitor 
the implementation of the designed social safeguard programs, including resettlement of the 
villagers in the reservoir area and implementation of a package of livelihood restoration and 
development for all affected persons. This will require that there be a social development 
specialist stationed in the Lao PDR to assist the Government on a routine basis. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The technical assistance is to ensure that the Project is implemented in accordance with 
its envisaged design as a world-class model, not only producing electricity for meeting the 
needs in the Lao PDR and Thailand but also doing so in a socially sustainable inclusive manner. 
The anticipated impact of the TA is that the livelihoods of the project affected people, particularly 
the  stated  income  targets,  will  be  restored  in  accordance  with  the  Project’s  concession 
agreement and ADB’s policies. The outcomes of the TA will be the assurance (i) that affected 
people on the Nakai plateau will be properly resettled, their livelihoods will be restored through 
appropriate implementation of agriculture, fishery and village forestry programs; (ii) that affected 
people  whose  lands  were  taken  for  the  Project  will  be  properly  compensated  and  their 
livelihoods restored in accordance with the concession agreement  and in compliance with 
ADB’s policies; and (iii) that villagers in the upstream and downstream areas will be provided 
with adequate and suitable options for restoring the potential loss of fish catch, riverbank 
gardens, and other livelihood opportunities in accordance with the concession agreement and 
ADB’s policies. The TA will also provide information for reports to ADB management and the 
Board of Directors on the Project’s implementation status, and for preparing responses to the 
numerous civil society organizations that maintain an interest in the Project. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  To achieve the intended outcomes, the technical assistance will continue the ongoing 
monitoring  of  the  project  implementation  through  constant  consultation  with  NTPC,  the 
Government of Lao PDR, and other IFIs. This requires that the Government has available to it 
the services of a specialist, who will join regular technical visits with World Bank teams to the 
project sites. In the past 2 years, the technical visits have proven very effective not only in 
identifying issues in the implementation of the social programs but also in exploring options for 
solving these issues with NTPC and the Government. 
 
11.  The TA will engage an international social development specialist who has worked 
extensively in the Lao PDR and has good experience in the country and with ADB’s social 
safeguard polices. The specialist will, together with other project IFIs (in particular the World 
Bank), assist the Government with conducting regular monitoring missions at least twice a year, 
and consult with the Government and NTPC to assist them in implementing the Project’s social

3
development programs. The work of the consultant and his or her outputs constitute the outputs 
for the TA. These will include aides memoire and meeting minutes documenting progress with 
regard to the implementation of the social development programs of the Project, including 
progress in 
 
(i)  achieving  income  targets  for  the  1,200  resettled  households  on  the  Nakai 
plateau,  
(ii)  the upstream and downstream program implementation, 
(iii)  final  compensation  and  livelihood  restoration  for  land  acquired  for  project 
construction, and 
(iv)  implementation  of  the  social  and  environmental  monitoring  framework  and 
operational plan for the Nakai Nam Theun National Protected Area.  
 
12.  The specialist will assist the Government with reviewing the Project’s social safeguard 
documents and providing comments as necessary, and will provide information that will be used 
for preparing reports and presentations to ADB’s Board and management about the progress of 
the Project. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $420,000 equivalent, of which $400,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will finance the 
balance  of  $20,000  equivalent  in-kind  by  providing  counterpart  staff  support  and  data, 
information, and reports. The detailed cost estimate and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
14.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA, which will be implemented over a 24-
month period commencing in July 2008. 
 
15.  An international consultant will be engaged on an individual basis by ADB for 12 person-
months  intermittently  over  2  years,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The consultant, who will be based in ADB’s 
Lao Resident Mission, will possess (i) in-depth knowledge of ADB’s policies on involuntary 
resettlement and indigenous peoples, (ii) experience in implementing social development plans 
for resettlement arising from large infrastructure projects, and (iii) excellent understanding of 
issues related to ethnic minorities in the Lao PDR. The outline terms of reference are in 
Appendix 3. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for the Greater Mekong Subregion 
Nam Theun 2 Hydroelectric Project – Social Safeguards Monitoring, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

Appendix 3  7
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANT 
 
 
1.  The technical assistance requires the service of an international social development 
specialist (12 person-months intermittent during a 2-year period). The consultant’s scope of 
work will be to provide assistance to the Government with monitoring the Nam Theun 2 project 
social programs including involuntary resettlement, indigenous peoples, and gender aspects of 
the Project. The specialist will report to the task manager of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
for the Project.  
 
2.  The consultant will undertake the following.  
 
(i)  Become familiar with all relevant project documentation, including (but not limited 
to) the concession agreement, loan agreement, social development plan (2005), 
social  and  environmental  management  first  operation  plan  (2005),  updated 
resettlement plans for project lands (2007), downstream implementation plan 
(2008),  international  financial  institution  (IFI)  missions'  aides  memoire,  and 
reports of the social and environment panel of experts, lenders’ technical advisor, 
independent monitoring agency, nongovernment organizations, and Nam Theun 
Power Company’s monthly reports. 
(ii)  Maintain  close  and  frequent  contact  with  the  World  Bank’s  Lao  People’s 
Democratic Republic-based staff responsible for monitoring the implementation 
of the social programs of the Project. 
(iii)  In coordination with the World Bank and other financiers as relevant, monitor the 
status of the Project’s social programs as per the Project’s legal documents; in 
particular the program for restoration of livelihood of resettlers on Nakai plateau, 
the  program  for  compensation  of  project  lands,  and  the  downstream 
development program. Identify potential problems and issues that may affect the 
achievement of the objectives of these programs, and propose solutions to these 
problems in consultation with the World Bank and IFI teams.  
(iv)  Participate in IFIs’ dialogue with Nam Theun 2 Power Company (NTPC) and the 
Government about the social programs, especially for identifying and resolving 
problems and difficulties. 
(v)  Review and provide written comments on various reports and documents as 
requested by ADB’s task manager. 
(vi)  Prepare  inputs  to  regular  briefings  and  presentations  and  reports  for  ADB 
management and the Board of Directors, and prepare responses to inquiries 
from civil society as requested by the task manager. 
(vii)  Participate in IFI review missions as requested by the task manager, provide 
technical guidance to NTPC and the Government, and contribute to mission 
aides memoire, back-to-office reports, and other documents. 
 
3.  The consultant will (i) provide ADB with brief reports each month highlighting the main 
issues in (ii), (iii), (iv), and (v) above; (ii) provide inputs as set out in (vi) above;  and (iii) provide 
quarterly reports to the Government counterpart agency with content to be agreed with the task 
manager.
